comments.commentBody:
Duke Snider played the game with a smile on his face and he always had time to
stand at the railing outside the Dugout at Ebetts Field and make small talk with the fans.In 1947 I remember Red Barber saying that Mr. Rickey felt that when Snider found the strike zone he would be one of the great players of his time. When I told this to Duke he thanked me for telling him this.story. After a game you could find Snider on the Prospect Park station going to his home in Brooklyn.He was a True Blue Brooklyn Dodger and he gave back to the fans the
feeling that he really appreciated the love that they felt about him. Thanks for the
memories Duke.

My grandmother was a typical immigrant Polish Jewish Mother, except for one difference. She was a BIG baseball fan. As I understand it, my Dad and my Uncle hogged the family radio and she became addicted to listening to Dodger games, whom she faithfully followed until they abandoned Brooklyn.

Duke Snider was her favorite, but she insisted that his last name was Shnider and that he was Jewish. Well she survived the Dodger abandonment, became a Mets fan, and lived to see them win 2 World Series (and lose a lot more games), but throughout her life she was certain that the two best Jewish hitters of all time were Hank Greenberg and Duke Shnider!

Many thanks to Steven Greenhouse, for an important article on an important topic which is now dividing Americans at an important time in our history.

Through the comments alone, one can see how divisive this issue has become. Comments from those in support of Gov. Walker, as well as comments in opposition to Gov. Walker, are passionate, to say the least. It is clear that our society is facing what may be a crucial turning point.

The good news is, in this country of ours, that we always have a choice. If we do not believe we are adequately paid by the government agency for which we work, we can always seek to better ourselves and our prospects in a private sector job. And, vice versa.

And, there’s more good news. If the demands of one sector of our economy become too expensive or too expansive, the power of the voting booth enables us to correct the problem.

For the selfish few whose heads are stuck in the sand, demanding more than their share of the pie, they should get down on bended knee and thank those who drafted our Constitution, for establishing and protecting their rights and their freedoms, as well as the rights and freedoms of the rest of us. Our founders were principled persons of extraordinary hope and vision, who had the foresight to furnish us with the mechanism for resolving our disagreements. May God always bless America.

I am watching Ozzie Osbourne in a Nationally Televised commercial for Best Buy, so bad behavior off screen is generally rewarded, not punished by TV Execs... While I agree with the points made in the article, Hollywood is a corporate medium, and the most we can expect from any corporate entity when one of its members "acts up" is "spin control", which is exactly what Mr. Lorre has done; i.e., silence the transgressor.

However, television content is trivial, and of the least importance when it comes to other issues that we face.
Shameful? Of course, but no less abhorrent than the swill that we endure over the air most of the time. It would be misguided to expect Film and Television studios to maintain a higher (or even "respectable") standard than the rest of the multi national corporations who regularly violate every other tenet of fairness and decency that we hold dear.
.
No surprise here.  It dovetails perfectly both with Hollywood's attitude toward women and the Republican war on women.
Clearly, the women who alleged the violence had no power to fire him but his boss, even to Charlie Sheen's greatest surprise, had.

This is the story of yet another, privileged, self destructive, overpaid and apparently talented and misogynistic actor. I haven't watched him in anything since PLATOON, which appears to have been the only serious, interesting role he's ever had. Why is this story considered newsworthy, his misogyny or that he's gotten away with it? His story is hardly unique.

If he'd actually experienced and survived combat in some useless, brutal war, as his character did in PLATOON, we'd likely never have heard of him and his recent conduct might be worthy of scrutiny. As it is, who really cares except people with little else to do but wring their hands about someone who has done nothing but make himself wealthy and those women foolish enough to tolerate his company, miserable. This guy is not Charlie Chaplin, Marlon Brando or Robert De Niro. He's not even comparable to Robert Downey Jr.

From the naive grunt whose eyes are opened and heart is broken in the amazing movie Platoon, is he now continually playing the role a scarred combat vet with PTSD who can't make peace with himself? Seems like it has been downhill since then. Time to join the civilized humans, Charlie Sheen, and relinquish those violent, sick fantasies that keep surfacing in the news.

Domestic abuse is not acceptable. I worked as a probation officer and dealt with offenders. Zero tolerance is the only policy acceptable. Domestic violence correlates closely with addictions. Most domestic abusers I encountered had substance abuse problems; not all substance abusers are domestic abusers. I agree that I have tolerated Mr. Sheen’s conduct by watching the sit-com. I am part of the problem.

I had been wondering for a long time what it would take for Charlie Sheen to "go too far."  He should have been canned a long time ago.  But I guess  keeping him on made sense---why fire someone for mistreating women when he is paid to pretend to mistreat women.  Maybe he just likes to practice a lot.

Wow, nice piece, Mr. Carr. This keeps happening: I read your stuff and am impressed, even gratified. ... I submit that this narrative of dysfunction, greed, desire, heedlessness in Hollywood and its corporate boardrooms is, in a broader sense, a narrative of the "Current Epoch" and where we are as a society (and spiritually as individuals). Individuals, businesses and institutions (whether religious, governmental, financial, etc.) operate in goofy, injurious ways, don't they?

Instead of reading about Mr. Barrett in the Times, I would much rather be reading pieces BY him on your pages. Don't eulogize him - hire him!
http://emcphd.wordpress.com/

Its good to see a former Holy Cross H.S. alumna making a difference. Back in the days in Lynchburg, Wayne and brother Larry stood out in espousing their views and backing them up.  I'm sorry to see Wayne was fired.  But, I am positive he will land on his feet on a dead run. God speed.

I was pretty young when the Voice began shifting from a truly respected alternate news source to a fluffy advertising circular.

(I was of the era when the New York Press -- briefly -- became a real competitor of the Voice, forcing them to give it away for free. Alas, the Press took a rapid nosedive in the late 90s, and the only remarkable thing about it these days is that it's still in print. It's main function seems to be to give Armond White a job.)

It's very sad to see this final nail in the coffin of independent journalism.

It's more than just the Voice though. Real journalism is dying out altogether, replaced by sloppy fluff pieces and not-even-remotely-objective bloggers.

Even the Paper of Record (cough) is more and more focusing on the low-hanging fruit -- fluff pieces, lifestyle articles, recipes, mommy filler... the kind of stuff that used to be the bread and butter of supermarket checkout magazines, not a serious news organ.

I truly a new model for the Fourth Estate emerges in the digital era. So far I haven't seen it at all. You have to pay and employ journalists like Wayne Barrett.
No one could make ethics as entertaining as you did. Your column was the best part of the Sunday Times and I'll really miss it.
Did anyone else ever notice that the letter signed "Anonymous, Connecticut" were always the most entertaining? Randy, you will missed.
I shall miss your column---but would have had to soon anyway because the the NYT paywall looming in the near future. At least NPR is a dot-org and not a dot-com.

I was so shocked when I opened the magazine this morning. I always read the magazine first, and the Ethicist right after checking the contents. Then I read "On Language" - also a farewell!!! What gives?! Is there going to be a magazine next week???

You'll be missed!

I have enjoyed your column, even conclusions with which I did not agree.  I have used some as examples in teaching ethics to physicians, social workers and other health professionals.  You will be missed.
Like many other commentators, I will miss this column. One of my favorites. I hope its demise does not mean the times is abandoning the practice of ethics?
We will miss you greatly.  You have been a delightful counselor and guide.  I'll look forward to a book from you soon.
god bye mr. Cohen, i´ll miss you , i´ll try to search you. i like your sincerity and honesty

I'd love to have seen this...
Best movie winner announced. "The King's Speech".

Spielberg hands Firth the Oscar -
then reaches into his pocket and hands him a peach.

The Kings Speech...over The Social Network??? No Best Director for David Fincher? I'm disappointed. I have no hard feelings towards The Kings Speech, but The Social Network was far far far superior to the competition. Is there a bias for Euro-centric (or British) plotlines to win the major awards?

Where were the real movie star icons tonight (apart from Clint Eastwood, and Speilberg) like Warren Beatty, Jack Nicholson, Robert Duvall, Angelina Jolie? Why aren't stars of that caliber up on stage, as the norm, instead of the rarest exceptions, handing out the more important awards?
